Needless to say, these can have NIP-22 comments/discussions.

title: Add NIP-AE: Agents

This PR adds some of the kinds I'm using in TENEX, it defines everything needed to instantiate an agent: agent definition, agent lessons and attribution.

[Read here](https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/blob/51a5be04186773e6ffffe80992e80ed0dfad2d44/AE.md)

title: NIP-XX: Responsive Image Variants (extending NIP-94)
body:
## Summary

This NIP extends [NIP-94](https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/blob/master/94.md) (File Metadata) to support multiple resolution variants of an image, enabling bandwidth-efficient responsive image delivery while preserving content-addressed integrity via Blossom.

### Key features:
- **Client-side variant generation**: Multiple resolution variants (128px thumb through 2560px desktop-lg + original) generated before upload
- **Content-addressed integrity**: Each variant has its own SHA-256 hash, uploaded as a Blossom blob
- **EXIF stripping**: All metadata removed from all variants for privacy
- **Binding event**: Kind 1063 event with `imeta` tags (one per variant) links all variants together
- **Viewport-aware selection**: Consuming clients pick the smallest variant >= their viewport width  pixel ratio
- **Discovery via `#x` queries**: Separate `x` tags enable finding the binding event from any variant hash

### Variant table:

| Variant | Target Width | Quality | Use Case |
|---------|--------------|---------|----------|
| `thumb` | 128px | 70 | Previews, galleries, feed thumbnails |
| `mobile-sm` | 512px | 75 | Small mobile, portrait viewing |
| `mobile-lg` | 1024px | 80 | Large mobile, small tablets |
| `desktop-sm` | 1536px | 85 | Laptops, small desktops |
| `desktop-md` | 2048px | 88 | Standard desktop displays |
| `desktop-lg` | 2560px | 90 | Large displays, HiDPI/Retina |
| `original` | native | 92 | Full resolution, EXIF stripped |

### Implementations

This NIP has been implemented and tested in three separate clients:

- **[Smesh](https://git.mleku.dev/mleku/smesh)**  React/TypeScript Nostr client with client-side variant generation via Canvas API
- **[ORLY](https://git.mleku.dev/mleku/next.orly.dev)**  Go relay with server-side variant generation (Lanczos resampling) and Svelte web UI with client-side generation

All three implementations (Smesh client-side, ORLY server-side Go, ORLY client-side Svelte) use identical variant names, target widths, and quality settings.

### Related NIPs

- Extends [NIP-94](https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/blob/master/94.md) (File Metadata)
- Follows the multi-`imeta` pattern from [NIP-71](https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/blob/master/71.md) (Video Events)
- Compatible with [NIP-92](https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/blob/master/92.md) (Media Attachments)
- Uses [Blossom](https://github.com/hzrd149/blossom) for content-addressed blob storage

 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

title: Stringify supported nips
body: This is supported by coracle, flotilla, and implemented by zooid. I'm making this change because of [NIP `9a`](https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/pull/2194)

title: NIP-57: Moves lud06 and lud16 from kind 0
body: Adds a new kind to store ln addresses for zaps and other receivables, removing the need to bug all kind 0 users with these settings that are only used if a client implements zaps and lightning flows.

title: NIP-XX: Nostr Relay Connect (NRC)
body:
## Summary

Nostr Relay Connect (NRC) is a protocol for accessing Nostr relays through encrypted tunneling via a public rendezvous relay. It enables:

- **Access to relays behind NAT/firewalls** - Personal relays on home servers, mobile devices, or networks without public IPs can be reached through any public relay
- **Client-as-relay pattern** - Any Nostr client can expose its local storage (IndexedDB, SQLite, etc.) as a relay endpoint, enabling cross-device sync without server infrastructure
- **Standard NIP-01 semantics** - Tunnels REQ, EVENT, CLOSE, COUNT messages transparently, so existing relay query logic works unchanged

### How It Works

1. Client wraps Nostr messages in kind 24891 events, encrypts with NIP-44
2. Rendezvous relay forwards based on `p` tags (cannot decrypt content)  
3. Bridge/listener decrypts and processes against local storage
4. Response wrapped in kind 24892, encrypted, returned via rendezvous relay

### Key Use Case: Client Bridge

The most interesting aspect is that **any Nostr client can act as a relay bridge**. A browser app, mobile client, or desktop application can:

1. Listen for NRC requests on a rendezvous relay
2. Process incoming NIP-01 queries against its local IndexedDB/SQLite
3. Return results through encrypted responses

This means users can sync between their own devices using their client's local storage as the sync target - no dedicated relay server needed.

Additionally, it can be used for any case where for reasons of the network (NAT, mainly) enabling users to access relays not able to listen directly to an internet address. In other words, this is an augmentation of the main websocket interface to cover this situation, an example might be a user wanting to archive all of the events that they see on one client, and another client that also has the access credentials can query this cache and enable an offline-first pattern for this use case. This use case is being implemented now so that smesh.mleku.dev and relay.orly.dev can do this - the relay connected using NRC can be used as a primary cache relay for a client, and though right at this minute i can't test this with an offline instance, i will demonstrate this later when my starlink arrives.

### Reference Implementations

- Go (bridge + client): [ORLY Relay](https://git.mleku.dev/mleku/next.orly.dev)
- TypeScript (client + listener): [Smesh](https://git.mleku.dev/mleku/smesh)

title: NIP-05: Moves from kind 0 to its own event kind.
body:
This PR moves the `nip05` property from kind 0 to its own kind `10008` so that we can: 
- have multiple nip05s.
- stop polluting kind 0
- filter 10008 events by nip05

It also rewrites the extremely verbose NIP-05 text without changing any behavior other than the new kind `10008`

Read [HERE](https://github.com/vitorpamplona/nips/blob/nip-05-with-kind-10008-2/05.md)

title: NIP-74: Podcasts
body: Here is a site you can use to test out the nip: https://www.transmit.fm/

title: NIP-FR: Add Friends-Only Notes
body: A mechanism to share encrypted notes with different sets of people

title: NIP58 - Badge Event "Request" and "Denial"
body:
# NIP-58 Extended - Badge Requests

`draft` `optional`

This aim for discussion to extend [NIP-58](https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/blob/master/58.md) with badge requests and denials.

## Motivation

NIP-58 defines badge creation and awarding but provides no mechanism for users to request badges. This extending would add:

- Users can request badges from issuers
- Issuers can formally deny requests
- Users can withdraw requests
- Issuers can revoke denials

## Event Kinds

| Kind | Name | Publisher | Type |
|------|------|-----------|------|
| 30009 | Badge Definition | Issuer | Addressable |
| 8 | Badge Award | Issuer | Regular |
| 30008 | Profile Badges | Recipient | Addressable |
| **30058** | **Badge Request** | **Requester** | **Addressable** |
| **30059** | **Badge Denial** | **Issuer** | **Addressable** |

## Badge Request (kind 30058)

An addressable event where a user requests a badge from an issuer.

```json
{
  "kind": 30058,
  "content": "<message to issuer>",
  "tags": [
    ["d", "30009:<issuer-pubkey>:<badge-d-tag>"],
    ["a", "30009:<issuer-pubkey>:<badge-d-tag>", "<relay-url>"],
    ["p", "<issuer-pubkey>"]
  ]
}
```

- The `d` tag MUST be the badge's `a` tag identifier
- This ensures one active request per badge per user
- Publishing a new request for the same badge updates/replaces the previous one

### Proof Tag

Requesters MAY include evidence to support their request:

```json
["proof", "<url, text, or nostr event id>"]
```

Multiple `proof` tags are allowed. Verification method is left to the issuer.

### Withdrawal

To withdraw a request, publish with `status` tag:

```json
{
  "kind": 30058,
  "content": "",
  "tags": [
    ["d", "30009:<issuer-pubkey>:<badge-d-tag>"],
    ["a", "30009:<issuer-pubkey>:<badge-d-tag>"],
    ["p", "<issuer-pubkey>"],
    ["status", "withdrawn"]
  ]
}
```

Clients MUST ignore or CAN honor requests with `["status", "withdrawn"]`.

## Badge Denial (kind 30059)

An addressable event where an issuer formally denies a badge request.

```json
{
  "kind": 30059,
  "content": "<reason for denial>",
  "tags": [
    ["d", "<request-event-id>"],
    ["a", "30009:<issuer-pubkey>:<badge-d-tag>", "<relay-url>"],
    ["e", "<request-event-id>", "<relay-url>"],
    ["p", "<requester-pubkey>"]
  ]
}
```

- The `d` tag MUST be the request event id
- This ensures one denial per request event

### Soft Denial

Denials are **soft** by design. A denied user CAN submit a new request for the same badge (e.g., with better proof). The new request generates a new event id, making the old denial obsolete.

### Revocation

To revoke a denial, publish with `status` tag:

```json
{
  "kind": 30059,
  "content": "",
  "tags": [
    ["d", "<request-event-id>"],
    ["a", "30009:<issuer-pubkey>:<badge-d-tag>"],
    ["e", "<request-event-id>"],
    ["p", "<requester-pubkey>"],
    ["status", "revoked"]
  ]
}
```

Clients MUST ignore denials with `["status", "revoked"]`.

## Request States

A request can be in one of four states:

| State | Priority | Condition |
|-------|----------|-----------|
| **Fulfilled** | 1 (highest) | Badge Award (kind 8) exists for this badge+user |
| **Denied** | 2 | Badge Denial (kind 30059) exists for this request |
| **Withdrawn** | 3 | Request has `["status", "withdrawn"]` |
| **Pending** | 4 (lowest) | Request exists, none of the above |

### State Resolution

```
1. Check for Badge Award (kind 8) from issuer to requester for this badge
    If exists: FULFILLED

2. Check request for ["status", "withdrawn"]
    If exists: WITHDRAWN

3. Check for Badge Denial (kind 30059) referencing this request
    If exists and not ["status", "revoked"]: DENIED

4. Otherwise: PENDING
```

### Edge Cases

| Scenario | Result |
|----------|--------|
| Award exists + Denial exists | Fulfilled (award takes precedence) |
| Request withdrawn + Denial exists | Withdrawn (denial invalid) |
| User re-requests after denial | New pending request (old denial obsolete) |
| Denial without valid request | Invalid (clients ignore) |

## Querying

**Issuer finds incoming requests:**
```json
{"kinds": [30058], "#p": ["<issuer-pubkey>"]}
```

**User finds own outgoing requests:**
```json
{"kinds": [30058], "authors": ["<user-pubkey>"]}
```

**User finds denials:**
```json
{"kinds": [30059], "#p": ["<user-pubkey>"]}
```

## Protocol Flow

```
USER                                              ISSUER
                                                    
                         
            Badge Definition                      
            (kind 30009)            
                         
                                                   
                discover                            
                                                   
                         
   Badge Request                         
            (kind 30058)            
            + optional proof                      
                         
                                                   
                             
                                              REVIEW      
                                         
                        
     WITHDRAW                                                
     status:                                                 
     withdrawn                 APPROVE         DENY         IGNORE
                                     
                                                  
                                   
                                 Award      Denial   
                                 kind 8    kind 30059
                                   
                                                 
               
    FULFILLED                                      
                                                   
  
    DENIED (can re-request)
  
           
   Accept to Profile       
            (kind 30008)            
           
```

## Examples

### Request with Proof

```json
{
  "kind": 30058,
  "pubkey": "a1b2c3...",
  "created_at": 1704067200,
  "content": "I contributed the auth module!",
  "tags": [
    ["d", "30009:x1y2z3:contributor"],
    ["a", "30009:x1y2z3:contributor", "wss://relay.damus.io"],
    ["p", "x1y2z3..."],
    ["proof", "https://github.com/project/repo/pull/42"]
  ]
}
```

### Denial with Reason

```json
{
  "kind": 30059,
  "pubkey": "x1y2z3...",
  "created_at": 1704153600,
  "content": "Please provide ticket confirmation.",
  "tags": [
    ["d", "req123..."],
    ["a", "30009:x1y2z3:attendee"],
    ["e", "req123...", "wss://relay.damus.io"],
    ["p", "a1b2c3..."]
  ]
}
```

## Backward Compatibility

Fully backward compatible with NIP-58:

- Existing kind 30009, 8, 30008 events unchanged
- Badge award without request still works
- Clients unaware of 30058/30059 simply ignore them

## Security Considerations

- Proof is self-reported; issuers must verify
- Requests are public; users should be aware
- Denial reasons are public; issuers may leave empty
- Clients should rate-limit requests to prevent spam

title: Nostr Web Tokens
body:
[Readable Version](https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/blob/c295284ff63b11c3466a521a582fc5dc61581585/WT.md)

TLDR;
A Nostr Web Token (NWT) is a Nostr event used to convey signed claims between parties on the web, inspired by JSON Web Tokens.

NWT is able to represent both [NIP-98](https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/blob/master/98.md) and [Blossom authorization event](https://github.com/hzrd149/blossom/blob/master/buds/01.md#authorization-events), and anything in between, allowing clients much more flexibility for how and how long these tokens are considered valid.

Depending on the use case, the benefits are improved signing UX and/or security.

Here is a detailed comparison: [NWT vs NIP-98 vs Blossom Auth](https://github.com/pippellia-btc/nostr-web-tokens?tab=readme-ov-file#comparisons)

Here is a video explanation: [Introducing NWT](https://primal.net/e/nevent1qvzqqqqqqypzpa5rapcrtaadfazwpwvvl0v4xlskg4df9nfcem7yevcaka2h7hhjqythwumn8ghj7un9d3shjtnwdaehgu3wvfskuep0qythwumn8ghj7un9d3shjtnswf5k6ctv9ehx2ap0qqsvm2eh4jxg8zm8z3zlqusuvjvyqa6sn2zm48amjr6l79xun0qjc9g7tg45r)

EDIT:  
Here is the reference library implementation: [Golang NWT](https://github.com/pippellia-btc/nwt)

title: NIP-50: Add Query Expression Extensions
body:
## Problem

The current NIP-50 specification for the `search` filter field is too vague and leaves critical implementation details undefined:

1. **Ambiguous multi-term behavior**: The spec says queries should be "human-readable" like "best nostr apps", but doesn't specify whether this means:
   - All terms must match (AND)?
   - Any term can match (OR)?
   - Phrase matching?
   - Something else entirely?

2. **No interoperability**: Different relays interpret the same query differently, making it impossible for clients to predict results or implement consistent UX across relays.

3. **No capability discovery**: Clients cannot determine what query features a relay supports, forcing them to either:
   - Assume minimal capabilities (limiting functionality)
   - Try advanced queries blindly (risking inconsistent behavior)

4. **Limited expressiveness**: Users cannot express complex queries like "cats AND dogs" or "bitcoin OR nostr" in a standardized way.

## Solution

This PR adds **optional** query expression extensions that relays can implement and advertise via NIP-11:

### 1. Boolean Operators
- Explicit `AND` / `OR` operators with clear precedence rules
- Parentheses for grouping
- Phrase matching with double quotes
- Backwards compatible: relays not supporting this continue working as before

### 2. Filter Attributes
- `limit:<number>` - control result count within the query
- `since:<timestamp>` / `until:<timestamp>` - time range filtering
- Allows more concise queries without duplicating filter object fields

### 3. Capability Discovery
- Relays declare support in NIP-11 via `nip50_search` object
- Clients can adapt their UI based on relay capabilities
- Example:
```json
{
  "supported_nips": [50],
  "nip50_search": {
    "boolean_operators": true,
    "filter_attributes": ["limit", "since", "until"]
  }
}
```

## Benefits

1. **Interoperability**: Clear specifications mean consistent behavior across implementations
2. **Backwards compatible**: All extensions are optional; existing implementations continue working
3. **Progressive enhancement**: Relays can implement features incrementally
4. **Better UX**: Clients can build powerful search interfaces when relays support advanced features
5. **Minimal changes**: Only ~45 lines added, preserving all original text

## Implementation Impact

- **For relay developers**: Optional extensions, can implement incrementally
- **For client developers**: Can query NIP-11 to discover capabilities and adjust UI accordingly
- **For users**: More powerful, predictable search experience on supporting relays

## Reference Implementations

To prove feasibility, I have implemented this specification in two languages:

- **Go**: https://github.com/mattn/go-searchquery
- **C++**: https://github.com/mattn/searchquery

These implementations demonstrate that the query parser can be:
- Implemented in ~300-400 lines of code
- Efficient and lightweight
- Easy to integrate into existing relay implementations
- Consistent across different languages

title: NIP-54: Switch from Asciidoc to Djot
body:
## Summary

This PR switches NIP-54 from Asciidoc to Djot format, as proposed in #2082.

Changes:
- Replace Asciidoc syntax with Djot
- Use Djot reference-style links for wikilinks (e.g., `[cryptocurrency][]` instead of `[[cryptocurrency]]`)
- Add JSON examples for Merge Requests and Redirects
- Add wikilink examples for non-Latin scripts
- Add "Why Djot?" section explaining the rationale

## Related

- Continues the work from #2082
- Builds on #2177 (d-tag normalization for non-Latin scripts)

body:
A proposal to replace the withdrawn NIP-EE which includes its use of base64 keypackages, but importantly has discussion of relay support.

See https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/issues/2175

title: NIP-63: Physical Space Rentals
body:
Add NIP-63: Physical Space Rentals

Defines event kinds for managing rentable physical spaces:
- 33001: Space Class
- 33002: Space  
- 33003: Availability Snapshot
- 33012: Pricing Configuration
- 33013: Rental Policy

Extends NIP-52 (kind 31922) for reservations.
Builds on NIP-41 for physical locations.

Working example here: https://pollerama.fun/feeds/topics/asknostr

DRAFT & WIP

I've started playing around with building weather stations. I will keep building / refining (with others - you?) the next months. 
It makes sense to be to have one kind for the weather station and one kind for each weather station reading. (A list of weather stations eg I operate, could also be handy - put that doesn't need to be reinvented here).
Wisdom / collaboration is welcome, and appreciated  
You can see some data being consumed here (from a proto kind): https://weather.shakespeare.wtf

title: NIP-32: describe use of Wikidata properties in labeling
body:
## Summary

This PR expands NIP-32 to include a standard method for using Wikidata properties within `l` and `L` tags.

## Motivation

Currently, when tagging external entities, it is often necessary to clarify what the entity is (e.g., a "communication protocol" vs. a "location"). Wikidata provides a robust ontology for this via properties like `P31` (instance of).

This proposal was conceived as an extension for implementing applications on top of [Thingstr](https://thingstr.pages.dev/) (See #2150). I would appreciate your feedback on this approach.

## Details

Explains how to format the tags using RDF-style prefixes (e.g., `wdt:P31`).

Provides a concrete example of a Kind 17 event reacting to the Nostr entity (`Q116423243`) and classifying it (`P31`) as a communication protocol (`Q132364`).

title: NIP-24: Add optional 'languages' field to kind 0 extra metadata
body:
This pull request proposes adding a new optional extra field called `languages` (plural, as an array) to kind 0 (user metadata) events in NIP-24.

The field is an array of strings following the IETF BCP 47 language tag format (e.g., `["en"]`, `["ja", "en-US"]`, `["es-AR", "fr", "en"]`), indicating the author's preferred languages in order of preference (first element = primary).

#### Motivation
Nostr is a global protocol with diverse multilingual users. Many people are fluent in multiple languages and want to indicate support for more than one.

A single-language field is limiting for such users. Changing to an array:
- Allows expressing multiple preferred languages with priority.
- Enables clients to suggest relays matching any or the primary language.
- Facilitates building and discovering language-specific or multilingual relays more effectively.
- Improves content discovery, filtering, and community features in multilingual environments.

title: Deprecate blurhash in favor of thumbhash
body:
As the title suggests, this PR deprecates blurhash in favor of [thumbhash](https://evanw.github.io/thumbhash).
It also adds thumbhash to kind:0.

It's already supported by favela.me (https://github.com/dtonon/fevela/pull/40)

Related discussion: https://njump.me/nevent1qvzqqqqqqypzqwlsccluhy6xxsr6l9a9uhhxf75g85g8a709tprjcn4e42h053vaqyd8wumn8ghj7urewfsk66ty9enxjct5dfskvtnrdakj7qgmwaehxw309aex2mrp0yh8wetnw3jhymnzw33jucm0d5hsqg9yz2u7g9tku2wu33t7ewwl2890w68demv792zad7m3uvdmezekq5z8vruj
